title: Royal Christmas Cards Reflect Family Bonds and Modern Image
summary: This article examines how royal Christmas cards from European monarchies this year emphasize tenderness and family closeness through images of hugging, holding hands, and linking arms. It highlights the Prince and Princess of Wales' card, which features an informal, relaxed scene in the Norfolk countryside with the family in casual attire, projecting a down-to-earth image as part of Prince William's approach to modernizing the monarchy. In contrast, a 1969 card shows royals standing apart stiffly, illustrating a shift from formal to relatable portrayals. King Charles and Queen Camilla's card, taken during a state visit to Italy, blends friendliness with formality, symbolizing unity amid a busy year. Prince Harry and Meghan's card includes festive snow from Canada, aligning with the holiday season. Overall, the article suggests that these cards serve to humanize royals, making them appear more accessible and family-oriented, which contrasts with historical formalities and reflects contemporary trends in royal communication.

King Charles and Queen Camilla's card, taken during a state visit, mixes formality with warmth, while Prince Harry and Meghan's card aligns with holiday themes. Understanding this context helps see how royal communication evolves to reflect changing public expectations and family values.
